. The community name derives from Spanish for "peak."

value: B Troop of the 4th US Cavalry Regiment at the annual Civil War re-enactment at Picacho Peak State Park

content=Directly along I-10 between Tucson and Casa Grande, this eroded volcanic outcropping is impossible to miss. The peak affords excellent views, and can be accessed via two difficult via ferrata routes, or by a strenuous hike. From mid-March until early April it is particularly photogenic with spring wildflowers following a good winter rainy season. In early March there is an annual Civil War re-enactment commemorating the Battle of Picacho Peak, one of several Civil War engagements in what was then Confederate Arizona Territory.
directions=I-10 north of Tucson, #219, take the frontage road SE
image=Ostriches at Rooster Cogburn ostrich farm 2.jpg

content=The ostrich will eat right out of your hand if you are brave enough, or there are feed chutes for the more conservative feeders. The deer are sweet and gently eat from your hand. The Rainbow Lorikeet Forest is a new attraction with small parrots that land on you and eat nectar out of your cup. There is also shopping for ostrich products.
content=A fun drive-through Mexican restaurant in nearby Eloy.
content=Open Sep-Apr. Spots for tents and RVs, cabins available. Hookups and water at some sites, showers and pool on the grounds. Wi-fi, pets accepted.

content=Between Tucson and Casa Grande (see listing above). Electric hookups and water at each site, suitable for RVs and tents. Modern bathroom facilities and toilets are on the grounds, and wifi is available for an extra fee.
